title: How to Keep Homegrown Produce Fresh for Market

steps.headline: Pick your produce at the last minute.
steps.description: The freshest will be that which is picked the latest.

steps.headline: Wash off any mud or dirt.
steps.description: Muddiness will detract from the appeal of the produce in the eyes of many consumers. Don't dig or scrape the fruit, however; gently wash off what will come off easily.

steps.headline: Keep cool and covered.
steps.description: All fresh produce appreciates being kept cool and if you have soft fruits, this is especially important. Keep covered from insects.

steps.headline: Put fragile produce into appropriate containers.
steps.description: Make sure to provide buffers between your fragile produce and the knocks and bumps of transportation. Keep items in plastic bags, crates, small plastic punnets etc. as needed.

steps.headline: Use refrigeration.
steps.description: If the climate is hot and the turnover is not fast, refrigeration is essential. Investing in suitable equipment can be a long-term savings if you plan on selling fresh produce frequently in a hot climate. If you don't have access to electrical refrigeration, innovate with ice chests or a pot-in-pot refrigeration system.

steps.headline: Keep herbs and green vegetables standing in water.
steps.description: Keeping the roots or stems in water helps to keep such produce fresh.

steps.headline: Consider how you display your fresh produce.
steps.description: If you at a market stall in hot weather, it is worth investing in a canopy to give shade over your produce during the day. If you are indoors, you might want to consider the backdrop that you use to highlight your produce - keep it simple, clean and bright to encourage customers to look at your produce.
